SourcedStatement: Now, officials at the plant told Morning Edition that the army is producing 36,000 shells a month, up from 24,000 just six months ago.
Name: Scranton Army Ammunition Plant
Justification: officials at the plant

SourcedStatement: The Tobyhanna Army Depot, which specializes in logistics support and radar equipment for foreign allies such as Ukraine, estimates that the company has a $2.4 billion dollar impact on the area and that it is the largest industrial employer in the region.
Name: Tobyhanna Army Depot
Justification: which specializes in logistics support and radar equipment for foreign allies such as Ukraine

SourcedStatement: Officials at Tobyhanna estimate that its average annual salary is $30,000 higher than the average salary in northeastern Pennsylvania, which is around $58,000 in 2021.
Name: Tobyhanna Army Depot
Justification: Officials at Tobyhanna

SourcedStatement: “We’re all about quality jobs, and that’s a quality organization,” Bob Durkin, the president and chief executive officer of the Scranton Chamber of Commerce said.
Name: Bob Durkin
Title: president and chief executive officer
Justification: the president and chief executive officer of the Scranton Chamber of Commerce

SourcedStatement: “So the infusion of additional funding to support is important to us.”
Name: Bob Durkin
Title: president and chief executive officer
Justification: the president and chief executive officer of the Scranton Chamber of Commerce

SourcedStatement: Congressman Matt Cartwright, who sits on the House Appropriations Committee and represents Scranton and other parts of Northeastern Pennsylvania pointed to a $277 million Raytheon contract to illustrate this point.
Name: Matt Cartwright
Title: Congressman
Justification: who sits on the House Appropriations Committee and represents Scranton and other parts of Northeastern Pennsylvania

SourcedStatement: “It’s not $277 million that stays here. But, you know, it’s a good chunk of it,” Cartwright said.
Name: Matt Cartwright
Title: Congressman
Justification: who sits on the House Appropriations Committee and represents Scranton and other parts of Northeastern Pennsylvania

SourcedStatement: “And it’s important that we keep that work coming.”

SourcedStatement: “I don’t really think that people dwell or concentrate on anything that’s going on outside of their sphere of influence,” Rich Hansen, the Commander’s Representative at the Scranton Army Ammunition Plant, said.

Title: Commander’s Representative

SourcedStatement: we’re kind of busy concentrating on what’s going on in Scranton.”

SourcedStatement: “We had a job fair in the middle of a heat wave and there was still a line going out of the door,” Danielle Weinschenk, the lead Public Affairs Specialist at the Tobyhanna Army Depot said.

SourcedStatement: “With the Ukraine support, you know, one day I was sitting there thinking about what needs to be done, and it kind of hit me that what we were doing directly affects whether people live or die,” said Jim Jarick, a senior technology center engineer at the Tobyhanna Army Depot.
Name: Jim Jarick
Title: senior technology center engineer
Justification: a senior technology center engineer at the Tobyhanna Army Depot

SourcedStatement: “If we aren’t doing our job correctly, people could die tomorrow. And that just put this whole thing in perspective for me.”

Title: senior technology center engineer
Justification: a senior technology center engineer at the Tobyhanna Army Depot

SourcedStatement: Mark Cancian, a senior advisor at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, told Morning Edition that Ukraine receives around 90,000 artillery shells a month, but that’s still not enough to keep up with Russia’s firing power.

Title: senior advisor
Justification: a senior advisor at the Center for Strategic and International Studies

SourcedStatement: “At the height of last year’s counteroffensive, the Ukrainians were firing about 6,000 a day, ” Cancian said.

SourcedStatement: “The Russians are [firing] probably about 10,000 a day.”

SourcedStatement: Col. Olksandr Popov, the commander of a Ukrainian artillery unit, estimates that they need about 30 to 40 shells to take out one Russian target, which is why these artillery shells are at the top of Ukraine’s list of needs.
